Award.AwardTitle: FW-HTF-P: Future Telemedicine Technologies and Multidisciplinary Workforce Readiness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: In the current healthcare environment, medical expertise is not evenly distributed geographically, and it is not possible to control the number or specialty of healthcare providers. Patients may need to travel a long distance or be on a lengthy waiting list to receive routine check-ups or specialty care. Delayed diagnosis can lead to higher cost and decrease quality of life. Hence, timely access to medical expertise must be provided regardless of location. To overcome the fundamental limitation in healthcare, a paradigm-shifting concept of medical expertise pooling has been identified to utilize existing medical expertise through the network. To materialize the idea, an advanced telemedicine system will be developed which can provide near in-person contact between patients and providers virtually in any distance. This research will encourage preventive or proactive healthcare for rural especially elderly populations and also help improve healthcare services for underserved populations suffering from disparities. Its educational integration will promote students to be biomedical workforce to support modern technology-intensive healthcare system.<br/><br/>The ultimate goal of the integrative research is to enable a near in-person telemedicine system that can connect healthcare providers and patients via a communication network to increase healthcare accessibility and optimize medical expertise resources. This will change the paradigm of public healthcare, routine check-ups, and early diagnosis from a per-request service to preventive and connected healthcare. The main goal of this planning project is to identify and establish key components of future telemedicine technologies and plan multidisciplinary education and workforce training. The telemedicine system development consists of three future technology fields: soft robotics for tele palpation, bioacoustics for tele auscultation, and network communication for integrating the system and managing data including cybersecurity. The technical objective of the project is to establish the core telemedicine technologies i.e., identification and proof-of-concept prototyping of tele tactile display, body sound sensing, and network communication. As a multidisciplinary effort, the College of Nursing will provide potential user feedback for the telemedicine system development and help design a user training plan. For educational integration, the project materials will be utilized as undergraduate course materials in each discipline and multimodal evaluation methods will be established. Subsequently, this planning project will lead to a well-established multidisciplinary research program that will advance knowledge and support education for future work.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ultimate goal of this highly integrative research is to enable a near in-person telemedicine system that can connect healthcare providers and patients via a communication network to increase healthcare accessibility and optimize medical expertise resources. This could change the paradigm of public healthcare, routine check-ups, and early diagnosis from per-request service to preventive and connected healthcare.

The main goal of this planning project was to identify and establish key components of future telemedicine technologies and plan multidisciplinary education that utilizes the technology developments to help train future workforce for healthcare services and related industries. Three core biomedical technologies including tactile display, body sound sensor, medical data synchronization, have been investigated and component level proof-of-concept prototype developments demonstrated that such technology could provide far advanced telemedicine capabilities such as remote touch, whole body sound acquisition, and synchronized medical data that could promote new diagnosis method developments.

The core technology developments have been utilized as biomedical research that multiple undergraduate and graduate students have participated in the technology developments and obtained valuable experiences as future healthcare technology workforce. The use of emerging telemedicine technology has been utilized for advanced practice nursing students and demonstrated that integrating such technologies in training provides positive learning experience and encourages further professional development as future healthcare workforce.

The development of the proposed telemedicine system will promote fundamental scientific research on each technology and could enable new paradigm telemedicine systems that can provide digital health information infrastructure. Synchronized multi-modality medical data such as vital signs, bodily sounds, palpation, and portable imaging could provide connected data that is not currently available. This telemedicine research will encourage preventive or proactive healthcare for rural especially elderly populations and also help improve healthcare services for underserved populations, suffering from various disparities. Utilization of synchronized medical data could advance personalized medicine and big data based healthcare.

The proposed telemedicine research, outcomes, and subsequent implementation efforts will have particular regional and local impacts. In 2021, Florida population reached 21.8 million, and people over 65 made up over 20.9 percent, many of them set in a suburban or rural areas distant from medical facilities. Regarding workforce training, Orlando Medical City will create up to 30,000 jobs and have a $7.6B impact on the economy over the next decade. There will be a great demand for healthcare-related workforce and graduate students considering modern technology-intensive healthcare system. The research and its educational integration will promote local students to be a biomedical workforce in the region.


Last Modified: 02/25/2023
Modified by: Sang-Eun Song
